translated: Huayan Dharma Realm Profound Mirror, Scroll 2
Tang Dynasty, Monk Chengguan of the Great Huayan Monastery on Mount Qingliang
Guan said: Next, regarding the four statements of phenomena in relation to principle, the first is that phenomena and principle
are not different, therefore
a single dust mote completely encompasses the principle of reality.
Second, phenomena and principle are not one, therefore
it does not destroy a single dust mote.
Third, because of not being one, it is not different, therefore
a single tiny dust mote encompasses the boundless true principle.
Fourth, because of not being different, it is not one, therefore
it encompasses the boundless principle while the dust mote is not large.
Contemplate this.
The commentary says:
The answer is regarding phenomena in relation to principle.
It answers the previous question of why a single dust mote pervading principle is not large, etc.
The first two statements clearly show the aspect of pervading principle without being large.
The first statement is a single dust mote pervading principle.
The second statement clarifies that it is not large.
The third and fourth statements directly answer the contradictory question.
The third statement clarifies that a single tiny dust mote pervades the great principle.
It is also the fourth sentence, although it pervades the principle, the dust is not large.
It only clarifies that phenomena and principle are neither the same nor different.
The two meanings are difficult to understand.
The contemplation says.
When the boundless principle of reality completely pervades a single dust mote,
in the external phenomena,
is there the principle of reality or not?
If there is principle outside the dust mote,
then it is not the entire essence pervading a single dust mote.
If there is no principle outside the dust mote,
then it is not the entire essence pervading all phenomena.
The meaning is very contradictory.

The text of the difficulty can be understood.
The contemplation says:
The answer is that because the principle of oneness melts,
many phenomena are unobstructed.
Therefore, it is completely inside and completely outside.
There is no obstruction and no hindrance.
Therefore, each has four statements.

The text below this is the answer, which then pairs the two gates.

Each is entirely in all,

The inside and outside are unobstructed.

The commentary says:
Next, the four propositions regarding phenomena are as follows.

Question: In terms of principle and phenomena, is one phenomenon internal or external?

what is considered internal and external?

Because both the one and the many are identical to principle.

Therefore it is necessary for them to be neither internal nor external in relation to each other.
The first pair of opposites, mutual pervasion, has been explained.
